intro: Draba tridentata, commonly known as the three-toothed whitlow, is a flowering plant native to arctic and alpine regions of North America. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cress plants. The plant is characterized by its small, white or pale yellow flowers and basal rosette of narrow, grass-like leaves. It typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils and is adapted to cold, harsh environments. Draba tridentata is often found in tundra and subalpine habitats, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local ecosystems.
